'''''Rhizomarasmius setosus''''' ([[synonym (taxonomy)|syn]]. '''''Marasmius setosus''''' or '''''Marasmius recubans''''') is a tiny whitish mushroom having a distinctive hairy stem.<ref name=Antonín/><ref name=FungaNordica/><ref name=SF/>  It has been given the vernacular name "Beechleaf Parachute".<ref name=NBN/>

==Description==
The species can be described as follows:<ref name=Antonín/><ref name="FungaNordica"/><ref name=MycoDB/> 
*The white cap is initially hemispherical and later flat.  It grows to about 0.5 cm in diameter.
*The gills are white and distant, and either adnate or somewhat decurrent. The spore powder is white. 
*The stem can grow to 4 cm long but is very long and thin, being only about 0.5 mm in diameter. It is white at the top and red brown lower down, with long white hairs (up to 1 mm), at least near the base when young.  
*The smell and taste are not distinctive.
*The spores are usually  spindle-shaped, but can be ellipsoid, or almond-shaped and measure roughly 10-14.5 μm x 4-6 μm.

==Naming and related species==
[[File:Coloured Figures of English Fungi or Mushrooms - t. 302.jpg|thumb|160px|left|Sowerby's original illustration of ''A. setosus'']]
The [[botanical name|species epithet]] comes from the Latin adjective "saetosus" or "setosus", meaning "coarsely hairy".  That word in turn derives from "saeta" (or "seta"), a bristle.<ref name=Lewis/> 

This species was originally described in 1801 as ''Agaricus setosus'' by [[James Sowerby]] in his historic work [[:commons:Coloured Figures of English Fungi or Mushrooms|"Coloured Figures of English Fungi or Mushrooms"]].  The French mycologist [[Lucien Quélet]] independently described the species under the name ''Marasmius recubans'' in 1873, but much later in 1987 [[Machiel Noordeloos]] determined that Sowerby's name takes precedence and defined the combination ''Marasmius setosus'' for it.  Then in 2015 Vladimír Antonín and Alexander Urban transferred it to the new genus ''[[Rhizomarasmius]]''.<ref name=SF/> 

''Marasmius saccharinus'' is a similar fungus which has been confused with ''R. setosus'' by some authors, but which, however, lacks the hairs on the stipe.  There are other tiny ''Marasmius'' species such as ''M. epiphyllus'' which are comparable but which again have a bald stipe.<ref name=Antonín/>

==Ecology and distribution==
This mushroom grows on dead [[beech]] leaves, or occasionally on other deciduous leaves such as [[willow]] or [[birch]].<ref name=Antonín/><ref name="FungaNordica"/>  It is widely distributed in central and western Europe.<ref name=Antonín/><ref name=FungaNordica/>
